ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The course is rather quick but does teach you the basics of multivariable calculus and linear algebra all in one semester. In the class, we learn to work with matrices, vectors, subspaces, Lagrange multipliers, and much more.
Learn basic linear algebra and multivariable calc skills.
Linear algebra and basic multivariable calculus
I learned concepts of linear algebra and multi variable calculus
How to do both lin algebra and calculus
Insightful course, helpful for multivariate calculus and linear algebra
I learned applications of multi variable calculus and linear algebra which would be particularly useful for future economics classes.
Learned about linear algebra and multi variable calculus
Basic linear algebra and differential MV CALC

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The class tries to fit a lot of material into one semester so it is rather quick. Despite that, it is very much manageable.

There is no formal organization of the course beyond a textbook, but we only take practice problems from the textbook. This makes it difficult to catch up and truly understand the material if you cannot make it to a class.

Strengths: You learn basic linear algebra and multivariable calc skills which can be useful if you're considering a pure econ major. Professor really wants you to succeed.  Weekly quizzes ensure you're on top of all the material and not falling behind.  Weaknesses: lectures were very hard to follow sometimes and sometimes it felt like you were teaching yourself the material.
There could be more engaging lectures
The quizzes allowed us to review concepts every week

Great professor, well taught 
Maybe sub spaces should not be included in syllabus

Strengths: The class gave me important concepts for the future classes I need. I liked Professor Rosenthal because he was available to meet a lot outside of class.

Weakness: The class could have been better organized. Sometimes the concepts felt weirdly out of place and the lectures were a little confusing.
Having weekly quizzes and review sessions every week was very helpful in the long term. The quizzes are very short (2 questions each), but motivate you to revise the material often.
Not very well staffed or supported

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: For economics majors, this class is recommended by the department itself and that is understandable. It teaches you the absolute basics that you need to know.
I think it is an easier alternative for social science/non-STEM students who need a math credit to MATH 120.

I would recommend this course only if you're a pure econ major.  Though we don't cover Lagrange multipliers until the very end it is a good enough course for the math requirement in the major without going too deep into multivariable calc.  I will also say if you took multi or linear algebra in hs, this class might also be a gut for you because you will be ahead of the material.  The professor really wants you to learn and cares deeply about his students although you do teach yourself a lot.  There is a peer tutor who I've heard is extremely helpful.  Truly, only take this class if you're an econ major.
Yes. Good way to do the math requirement for econ major. Not a particularly hard class at all.
Sure if you are on econ track

I would recommend this class if you need it to fulfill a math requirement as an econ person. I think this class gives you the important concepts to understand for the future without having to take math 120 or math 222. However, if you are taking this class out of interest or to continue with math I would recommend the 120 and 222 route more.
Yes, take it if you're unsure in your math skills before intermediate Econ courses.
No, unless they need a math credit and are a Econ major
If you need the math prereq
No, the professor is so bad at lecturing/teaching. Otherwise the content is good; the course is condensed well for its purpose. Maybe just take it with another professor.
